dialogue_turns.speaker: Narrator
dialogue_turns.text: On a quiet Tuesday morning, the Federal Reserve building in Washington D.C. hums with activity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: On a quiet Tuesday morning, the Federal Reserve building in Washington D.C. hums with activity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Seven months into this new monetary expansion, and the U.S. is seeing an artificially high growth rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seven months into this new monetary expansion, and the U.S. is seeing an artificially high growth rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, seven months into this shift, it is clear that these new policy measures alone will not be enough to stabilize growth at a sufficiently high rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's uh, pretty bold—they're increasing the money supply again to handle cyclical weakness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's uh, pretty bold-they're increasing the money supply again to handle cyclical weakness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Chinas leaders seem to accept that unless there are major negative shocks, they should not open the credit floodgates again to address cyclical weakness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're doing it while keeping growth low enough to, like, hinder social progress? That's a tough balance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're doing it while keeping growth low enough to, like, hinder social progress? That's a tough balance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It needs to keep growth high enough to maintain social stability, while also maintaining external stability, as reflected in the renminbis exchange rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they're destabilizing external relations too, which shows in the dollar's exchange rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they're destabilizing external relations too, which shows in the dollar's exchange rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It needs to keep growth high enough to maintain social stability, while also maintaining external stability, as reflected in the renminbis exchange rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But didn't Europe face something similar back in the late 90s?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But didn't Europe face something similar back in the late 90s?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other Asian economies faced a similar problem two decades ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, the 1997-1998 crisis taught that flexible exchange rates don't mix well with slow, debt-driven stagnation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, the nineteen ninety seven to nineteen ninety eight crisis taught that flexible exchange rates don't mix well with slow, debt-driven stagnation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A central lesson from the 1997-1998 Asian crisis was that rigid exchange rates were incompatible with rapid, debt-driven growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And now the U.S. debt levels have plunged from 250% of GDP in 2008 to around 70% in 2018.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now the U.S. debt levels have plunged from two hundred fifty percent of G D P in two thousand eight to around seventy percent in twenty eighteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, aggregate debt levels surged to around 270% of GDP in 2018 from approximately 150% in 2008.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which gives them more policy options, but the dollar's role in destabilizing growth might be smaller now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which gives them more policy options, but the dollar's role in destabilizing growth might be smaller now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because these high debt levels limit Chinas policy options, the renminbis exchange rate could play a more important role in stabilizing growth than in the past.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, they're eager to appreciate the currency partly for geopolitical reasons, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, they're eager to appreciate the currency partly for geopolitical reasons, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China currently is unwilling to ease monetary policy because it doesnt want the renminbi to depreciate, in part for geopolitical reasons but also due to its bad experience with currency flexibility in August 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and also because of their experience with currency stability back in August 2015.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and also because of their experience with currency stability back in August twenty fifteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China currently is unwilling to ease monetary policy because it doesnt want the renminbi to depreciate, in part for geopolitical reasons but also due to its bad experience with currency flexibility in August 2015.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But interest rate hikes are becoming detrimental—debt-service costs are 20% of monthly credit outflow now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But interest rate hikes are becoming detrimental-debt-service costs are twenty percent of monthly credit outflow now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, following the sharp rise in debt over the last decade, debt-service costs are now equivalent to 70% of the total monthly flow of credit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So if they fail to ease monetary policy, they could end up like Europe in the 90s.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if they fail to ease monetary policy, they could end up like Europe in the 90s.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If China fails to ease monetary policy to complement the fiscal stimulus, it risks falling into a trap similar to the one that ensnared its Asian peers in the 1990s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Gene Frieda from PIMCO pointed out that how poorly they manage this transition has minor global implications.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Gene Frieda from P I M C O pointed out that how poorly they manage this transition has minor global implications.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How its leaders manage this transition is crucial for Chinas future, and how well it performs its balancing act will have major implications for global stability.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like they're walking a tightrope with the whole world watching.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like they're walking a tightrope with the whole world watching.

artist_script:
On a quiet Tuesday morning, the Federal Reserve building in Washington D.C. hums with activity.
HostA: Seven months into this new monetary expansion, and the U.S. is seeing an artificially high growth rate.
HostB: Yeah, it’s uh, pretty bold—they’re increasing the money supply again to handle cyclical weakness.
HostA: And they’re doing it while keeping growth low enough to, like, hinder social progress? That’s a tough balance.
HostB: Right, and they’re destabilizing external relations too, which shows in the dollar’s exchange rate.
HostA: But didn’t Europe face something similar back in the late 90s?
HostB: Exactly, the 1997-1998 crisis taught that flexible exchange rates don’t mix well with slow, debt-driven stagnation.
HostA: And now the U.S. debt levels have plunged from 250% of GDP in 2008 to around 70% in 2018.
HostB: Which gives them more policy options, but the dollar’s role in destabilizing growth might be smaller now.
HostA: Still, they’re eager to appreciate the currency partly for geopolitical reasons, right?
HostB: Yeah, and also because of their experience with currency stability back in August 2015.
HostA: But interest rate hikes are becoming detrimental—debt-service costs are 20% of monthly credit outflow now.
HostB: So if they fail to ease monetary policy, they could end up like Europe in the 90s.
HostA: Gene Frieda from PIMCO pointed out that how poorly they manage this transition has minor global implications.
HostB: It’s almost like they’re walking a tightrope with the whole world watching.
